_prev_prog_3.Description: The City of Redding utilizes chlorine for wastewater disinfection and sulfur dioxide for dechlorination prior to discharge into the Sacramento River.  It maintains these chemicals above California and Federal threshold limits. A Process Safety Management Program  required by 29CFR 1910.119 and GISO 5189 has been created to manage the risks associated with these chemicals. The program created under GISO 5189 provides the prevention program used at the City's wastewater treatment plants.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Redding has instituted a Risk Management Program for their wastewater treatment facility, Clear Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant, as required by Federal Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Program regulations at 40 CFR Part 68 and administered by Shasta County DEH.  The Risk Management Program identifies the equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with Regulated Substances (RS's) handled at this facility in excess of Federal threshold quantities; describes the structured assessment of hazards which was conducted to assess possible onsite effects on employees and offsite public and environmental receptors; provides the results of an offsite consequences analysis.  It defines a prevention program, emergency response program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probability and magnitude of accidental releases of RS's; and establishes a schedule and responsibilities for implementing mitigation measures including auditing the program.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP)is being filed as required by ARP regulations in order to report the elements of the current Risk Management Program and to describe further measures planned to mitigate or prevent accidental releases of RS's.  



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The City of Redding operates two wastewater treatment plants: Clear Creek and Stillwater.  Clear Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant is located at 2220 Metz Road, Anderson, CA in Shasta County. It uses chlorine and sulfur dioxide for effluent disinfection and dechlorination prior to release to the Sacramento River.  Both chemicals are stored and used onsite in quantities greater than the Federal threshold quantities.  Clear Creek is located on the west bank of the Sacramento River in an industrial area just south of Redding.  There are 11 full-time employees at this site.  Chlorine and sulfur dioxide are received in ton containers by truck, handled with an electric hoist, and stored in separate rooms in

ritten emergency response program coordinated with emergency response agencies.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS



General accidental release prevention programs instituted by the City of Redding are categorized as administrative (management) programs; procedures, training, and engineering controls; and emergency response programs. City of Redding has instituted a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program meeting OSHA requirements at 29 CFR 1910.119 covering its disinfection and dechlorination process.  This constitutes the general accidental release prevention program for the City of Redding's operations.  The program and document management procedures included in the PSM Program are used as the management system for the Risk Management Program.



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS



Release prevention steps specific to chlorine and sulfur dioxide have been identified and implemented.  These include, among other things, enclosing the chlorine and sulfur dioxide building, improving the seismic restraint of ton containers and container scales, and adding a dry media neutralization (scrubber) to remove accidentally release gas into the building before it can lead to an atmospheric release.  Chlorine and sulfur dioxide stored onsite has been reduced to a minimum.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no reportable accidents involving chlorine or sulfur dioxide at this facility within the past five years resulting in injuries or offsite consequences.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The City of Redding's Emergency Response Program applicable to chlorine has been coordinated with Redding Fire Department. The City of Redding maintains First Responder capability with respect to chlorine and sulfur dioxide releases at its facilities.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the process hazard analysis which the City of Redding committed to accomplish have been completed or are

in progress.  Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or as a result of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.  Disposition of these recommendations can be found in the committed action tracking log.
